Vera Cruz Mexico.
August 29th,1922.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I was greatly encouraged and very much pleased to
receive your letter of August 17th. The fact is that
the work I am doing down here has a greater personal int-
erest than any work I have ever engaged in. I am so
desirous that the work be done well, and that the work
under my direction stand every test, that I have become
a material part of it. It was that reason, and the
additional one, that I knew you are interested in every
phase of the work, that I burdened you with my report.

1. The work in Tampico was undertaken in December of
1920, under the auspices of the Associated Oil Managers.
This association is composed of the managers of each of
the oil companies operating in the Tampico field and has
has for its purpose that promotion of the oil companies'
interests' of whatever character. It is purely egoistical
in character and purpose, and is never prompted by altru-
istic motives except when such motives redound to the
advantage of the oil companies. This the assocoiation free-
ly states.

In addition to other matters, sanitation and the care
of sick employes interests their attention. They were hav-
ing yellow fever, that was tying up their ships, and they
were seriously inconvenienced in the field by that incid-
ence of malaria among their employes. They had as their

Medical and Sanitary advisor, Dr. A.R. Stubbs, who when the
situation exit got beyond control, advised them to ask
your service for the loan of Le Prince. This was accompl-
-ished, and Le Prince came down on a four months tour of
duty generously loaned to these people by the Service.

Le Prince at once took charge, instituted the fish
campaign, and soon had yellow fever under control in Tampico
and had contributed a great deal towards the reduction of
the malarial incidence. The Associated Oil Managers sup-
plied all funds for the work, which aggregated $180.000.00
Le Prince demonstrated the utility of fish in Mexico for
the first time, from December 1920 to March 1921.

2nd. The Ojitlan epidemic would have burned out
without our assitance - in Ojitlan. The town is isolated
and is rather off the usual travel routes. It was introduc-
ed into the little place by soldiers who had visited
Tierra Blanca, at that time Badly infected. I am of course
referring to yellow fever. Indeed it had burned out, to
all practical purposes when we institued our campaign, but
our campaign, undoubdtedly prevented further spread among
the India's to the West and South.

When I first began the work, I wanted to start
the campaign on an intelligent basis, both as to the length
of each of our “vueltas”, and from an economical standpoint
as to the number of men I should employ. I made a survey
of the number of houses in Vera Cruz with the number and
character of containers. I placed a dozen men at work
and personally checked their work back of them to ascertain

the number of premises which an average inspector
could carefully revise each day. From my observations I
concluded that a good Inspector could cover from 80 to
100 houses as the are located in Vera Cruz in each 8-
hour day. Le Prince thinks that they could do more and
in one of his reports states that in Tampico his Inspec
-tors revised successfully and satisfactorily 260 houses
per day. That is impossible from a standpoint of careful
or satisfactory work.

After this was determined, I had to find out the
Minimum, safe period for each “vuelta”. I did this by
growing my own stegomyia. I found that under laboratory
conditions, rather more favorable, I think than natural
conditions, that I had from 36 to 48 hours after ovipos-
it, before hatching commenced, this continued for another
30 to 40 hours. I found 120 hours to be the average
time between the appearance of larvae and the the
appearance of the first pupa, and I found pupal life to
continue from 30 to 40 hours sometimes longer. Under
favorable conditions the cycle in Laboratory was of
from 7 3/4 to 8 2/3 days. I therefor took the min-
imum as the length of my vuelta. This for the sake of
security, and to make due allowance for a reasonable
per cent of failure to locate all breeding places
on the part of my Inspectors. I expect each inspector
to average 80 houses each day in the more central
portions of a town and 100 in the buburbs where the
water containers are more easily located, and the prem-
ises less difficulty to inspect thoroughly.

I agree that in nature the egg to imago cycle is
longer, but under favorable climatic conditions, and in
containers in the laboratory, where the water was never
agitated, and always protected from sun and shock, the
cycle was between 8 and 9 nonesdays, perhaps nearer 9 days,
on the average, than 8.

The cycle varied with the climatic changes, varying
from the minimum when the weather was warm and no winds
to speak of during the July to Sept. months, to 13 and 14 days
when the thermometer was around 65 and the Northers
were blowing, during the Fall and Winter months. In such
clmiatic conditions, there would be periods of 4 or more
days when all creative proceedure upon the part of the
adult as well as on the part of the pupa and larva was
apparently suspended, or at best very reluctant.

We examine for larvae with an ordinary flash light
But I have trained my inspectors to take plenty of time
and locate the one and two day old larvae, if they exist.
In fact the Inspctor studdies the container, and waits
quietly and patiently for a time sufficiently long to
permit the larvae and pupae to recover from their fright
of the approaching shadow and come up for air. I regard
the finding of pupae in any container, by the revisador,
as reflecting upon the care and efficiecieny of the
Inspector and repeated findings results in the dismissal
of the guilty man.

We have a variety of good fish around Vera Cruz
but I cannot locate your “Life”. I am now convinced f
from the results of my work here, that fish can be of

the greatest possible value in malarial control, in the
States, if a variety can be located that will thrive and
reproduce as some of our tropical varieties do, under
tropical conditions. I believe that it will solve the
problem for many small communities and if generally
introduced will minimise the problem for our larger
cities. I mean the growing of these varieties in the
ponds, ditches, larger holes and other anopheles breeding
places, which contain water in sufficient quantity to
support fish life during several months of the year. It
would be the most economical and most effective of re as-
ures and would finally result in the eradication of
malaria from certain communities now badly infected.
I would like to see it tried intelligently and from a
rational rather than from an empirical standpoint.

I was so glad to hear from you. Dr. White is in
Tampico. They had a recurrence there, in one of the places
which so aptly justifies your statement that it is"
“More important to work in places liable to be infected”
I am so firmly convinced of this that I am sure, the
Mexican campaign can never be completed, until such places
are covered with several vueltas of intensive work.

Conner is in Merida and Scannell is in Tam-
Pico. My Zone stills remains free and I anticipate no
trouble this year. I have done my work thoroughly in such
places where brigades have been established, and my in-
cidence is very low. I can maintain it indefinitely.

I was so glad to hear from you. If I can give
you any information at any time, let me know. With
my kindest regards to Miss Laura and yourself, I remain,
